bibl.title: Sacred Stories of the Sweet Grass Cree
bibl.series: National Museum of Canada, Bulletin no. 60, Anthropological Series, no. 11

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

p.seg: kîtahtawê itah ê-wîkicik awa mistanask owîkimâkanah sikâkwah , nama kêkway otawâsimisah . Once upon a time there dwelt somewhere Badger and his wife, Skunk, and they had no children at all.

awah sikâkoskwêw ostêsah wâkayôsah âyimisiyiwa , êh-kâsakêyit , kâh-kiyipah êh-kitâyit omîciwiniwâwa . This Skunk-Woman's elder brother was Grizzly, and he was a terrible glutton, who always in a jiffy ate up all their food.

êkwah nama kêkway nihtah-nipahtâw awa wâkayôs , êkwah awa mistanask mistahi nôhtêhkatêw ; wîh-nipahâhkatosôw . And this Grizzly was not good at killing anything. [sic] So Badger went hungry much of the time; he nearly starved to death.

ômis îtwêw awa mistanask :
notokêsiw , ka-nipahâhkatosonânaw . This is what Badger said: “Wife, we shall be starving to death.

seg.gloss: “I shall tell your brother so;
seg.note: LB: We are not told what he will say.

seg.gloss: perhaps he will be willing to let us go.
Only in this way can we stay alive.”
“Yes, do that!”

p.seg: tâpwê ntomêw wîstâwah ôhi wâkayôsah . So he called his brother-in-law, Grizzly.

êh-pîhtokêyit ,
ahâw , ta-tawâw ! itêw wîstâwah wâkayôsah ; When he came into the tent, “Good, come in!” said he to his brother-in-law, Grizzly;

omis îtêw :
nîstâ , kicîsimitin ; namoya ka-mîcisoyan kâ-ntomitân . thus he spoke to him: “Brother-in-law, I am disappointing you; it is not to a meal that I am calling you.

seg.gloss: I have nothing to eat;

seg.q: mâka ômisi ê-wîh-ititân , k-ôh-nitomitân : ahâw , nîsta , kitimâkihtawin ; kitimâkinawin .
seg.gloss: it is only to tell you something, that I have called you: now, brother-in-law, hear me with pity; take pity on my plight.
I beg this if you; let me go; let me go away from here; let me look for something to eat.
Your sister is almost dead from hunger.

p.seg:
piyis miskamânih ta-mîciyahk , nipahakwâwih mostoswak , nika-pê-kîwân , ta-pêtâyân wiyâs , itêw wîstâwah ;
osâm ôtah kisiwâk nama kêkway mostos , itêw wîstâwah , ê-wîh-wayêsimât ; If, in time, I find something for us to eat, if I kill some buffalo, I shall come back here and bring meat,” he told his brother-in-law; “for hereabouts there are no buffalo at all,” he told his brother-in-law, meaning to deceive him;
osâm êh-kitimahikot , êôkô ohci k-ô-wîh-sipwêhtêt . because the other too cruelly abused him, was why he wished to go away.

âhag , itwêw wâkayôs ,
tâpwê , nîstâ , ka-miywâsin , nipahacih mostos . “Very well,” said Grizzly; “Indeed, brother-in-law, it will be well if you kill a buffalo.
anohc nama kêkway nimîcison nîsta , itwêw wâkayôs . At present I too have nothing to eat,” said Grizzly.
tâpwê miywêyihtam awa mistanask , êh-pakitêyimikot wîstâwah . Truly, glad was Badger that his brother-in-law gave him leave to go.
tâpwê êkwah kawisimôwak , êh-nipâcik . So then they went to bed and slept.
êh-wâpahk , êh-kîkisêpâyâyik , wawêyîw awa mistanask , êh-picit . In the morning, at early day, Badger made ready to move camp.

êkwah êh-sipwêhtêcik , êkwah ômis îtwêw awa mistanask :
hâw , ôma kâ-wî-sipwêhtêyân , ta-mâyi-kîsikâw ; ta-mispon ! itwêw . Then, as they set out, then Badger spoke thus: “now then, when I set out, let there be foul weather; let it snow!” he spoke.
êkos ê-sipwêhtêt , tâpwê , namoya wâhyaw êh-ihtât , âsay misponiyiw . So when he departed, really, he had not gone far, and already it was snowing.
namoya kisinâyiw . It was not cold.
pa-pimipiciw kapê-kîsik , piyisk nama kâkway mêskanaw om îtah kâ-pê-pimohtêt . He went along with his camp all day, until there was no trail at all in the place where he marched.
piyis tipiskâyiw . At last night came.
âhci pikoh pa-pimohtêwak ; wâpani-pimohtêwak owîkimâkanah . Still they marched on; they tramped on till dawn, he and his wife.
êyôko mînah kapê-kîsik êh-pimohtêcik , êh-at-ôtâkosiniyik , kâ-wâpamât mostoswah . When they had marched all of that day, too, as evening came on, he saw some buffalo.
hâ nôtokêsiw , êkos ê-pimâtisiyahk ; mostoswak ôki nika-minahon , itwêw mistanask ; “There, old woman, now we can live; I shall make a killing of these buffalo,” said Badger;
hâw , ôma kâ-sakâk êkotah ntawi-kapêsih , itêw owîkimâkanah . “There, go camp over in that grove,” he told his wife.
êkwah wiyah itohtêw , ôhi mostoswah ê-wîh-kakwê-nipahât . And he went to try and kill the buffalo.
tâpwê êh-cikahkwâtât , kahkiyaw nipahêw . Indeed he threw his spear at them and killed them all.
miywêyihtam ê-wîh-mêscihât . He was glad when he saw that he was going to get all of them.
êkwah pôni-misponiyiw . Then it stopped snowing.
êkwah êh-wiyanihâcik , êh-pâh-pahkwêkiswâcik , kahkiyaw wiyâsah otinamwak ; nama kêkway wêpinamwak . Then they cleaned them and took off the hides and took all the flesh; they wasted none of it.
cikêmâ mistahi kî-nôhtêhkatêwak . No wonder, for they had suffered much from hunger.

mistê miywêyihtam awa sikâkoskwêw , iyikohk wiyâs êh-wâpahtahk ,
namoya nka-nipahâhkatosonân , êy-itêyihtahk . Skunk-Woman was happy to see so much meat, thinking that, “Now we shall not starve.” LB on {nka-nipahâhkatosonân}: In monologue the Cree (like the Fox and the Menomini) use the first person plural in the exclusive form, as if addressing some being not involved in the act.
êkwah nâhah wâkayôs mistahi nôhtêhkatêw . Then that Grizzly in yonder place got very hungry.

êkwah kaskêyihtam êkâ êh-takosiniyit wîstâwah ,
mâskôc nipahêw mostoswah , êh-itêyihtahk . He grew restless when his brother-in-law failed to arrive, thinking, “No doubt he has killed buffalo.”
êkwah nôhtê-ntonawêw wîstâwah . He wanted to look for his brother-in-law.

seg.gloss: “Ho, suppose I go look for Badger;

p.seg: mâskôc nipahêw mostoswah , itêyihtam ô wâkayôs , êkwah êh-sipwêhtêt . no doubt he has killed buffalo,” thought Grizzly, and went forth.
namoya wâpahtam itah êh-kîh-pimohtêyit ; cikêmâ kîh-misponiyiw ; wanihêw mistanaskwah . He could not see where the other had gone by; for, of course, it had snowed; he lost Badger's trail.
piyisk kâwih kîwâw , êkâ h-miskawât owîstâwah . At last he went back home, unable to find his brother-in-law.
êkwah awah mistanask âsay mînah wâpamêw mostoswah ; mîn êyôkoni kahkiyaw nipahêw . Then that Badger again saw some buffalo; these too he killed, all of them.
mîn êyôkoni kahkiyaw otinêwak ; nama kêkway wêpinamwak . These, too, they took entirely; they threw nothing away.
mistahi ayâwak ka-mîcicik . They had much to eat.
êkwah awah wâkayôs sipwêhtêw , âsay mînah ê-ntonawât wîstâwah . Then Grizzly set out to look again for his brother-in-law.

piyis nîswâw êh-nipât , êkoyikohk miskawêw mistanaskwah , mistah êh-ayâyit mîciwin , êkwah wiyah ê-wîh-nipahâhkatosocik otawâsimisah owîkimâkanah . At last, after two nights on the road, he found Badger, found him in possession of much food, while he and his wife and children were starving.
mistahi miywêyihtam ê-miskawât wîstâwah . He was very glad to have found his brohter-in-law.

ômis îtwêw :
hay hay hay ! êkwah kê-mîcisoyân , nîstâw êh-otihtak , mistahi êh-ayât wiyâsah , itwêw awa wâkayôs . He cried, “Splendid! Now I shall eat, now that I have come to my brother-in-law, who has so much meat,” said Grizzly.

êkwah tâpwê asamâw ; ma-mîcisôw ; iyâta-pôni-mîcisoci , kiyipah nôhtêhkatêw . And so, really, he was given food; he ate and ate; even though he finished meal after meal, right off he was hungry again.
êkwah êh-kîsitêpowiht , êh-asamiht , piyisk tipiskâyiw . So, as he was cooked for and served, night came on.
namoya wîh-nipâw , kapê-tipisk êh-mîcisot ô wâkayôs . He felt no need of sleep, but ate all through the night, that Grizzly.
piyisk wâpaniyiw . At last day broke.

seg.q: hâhâw , nîstâ , kâhkêwakwah ta-tahkopitam nisîm , ka-kîwêhtatâyân .
seg.gloss: “Hoho, brother-in-law, let my sister tie up dried meat for me to take home.

p.seg: mistahi nôhtêhkatêwak kitihkwatimak , kimis mîna , itwêw . Your nephews are very hungry and your sister,” he said.
tâpwê mistahi tahkopitam , ta-nayahtamiyit . So she tied up a great amount of it, for him to carry on his back.

êkwah ê-wîh-kîwêt awa wâkayôs , ômisi itêw :
hâ , nistâ , kîh-nîso-tipiskâkê nika-pâpitisin , itwêw wâkayâs . Then, when Grizzly was ready to go home, he spoke: “Now, brother-in-law, two nights from now I shall move my camp to this place,” said Grizzly.
êkosi êh-kîwêt . So then he went home.

êkwah omisî itwêw mistanask :
êkosi ihtik ânih kê-kitimahikoyahk mînah , nôtokêsiw , kistês , hâw , tahtoh êh-miywâsikih kikâhkêwakoma kâtâh . Then thus spoke Badger: “So it is in this way that your brother will again reduce us to misery, wife. Now, do you hide the best of your dried-meats. LB on {ihtik}: Probably read {êcik}.
takohtêtwâwi , kahkiyaw tit-ôtinam kimîciwininawa , itêw owîkimâkanah . When they come here, he will take away all our supplies of food,” he said to his wife.
tâpwêw kâtâw âtiht , êh-wâtihkêt pîhcâyîhk wîkiwâhk , êkotah êh-asiwatât omîciwinah . Accordingly, she hid some, digging a pit within the tent and putting in her store of food.
êkwah awah wâkayôs kâ-kîwêt wâpani-pimohtêw . And that Grizzly, going home, marched all night.
êh-otâkosiniyik , takohtêw owîkiwâhk . In the evening he arrived at his camp.
mistahi pêtâw ka-mîciyit tawâsimisah . He brought a great deal for his children to eat.
mistahi miywêyihtamiyiwa . They were very glad.

ômis îtwêw :
mihcêt nipahêw mistanask mostoswah . This is what he said: “Badger has killed many buffalo.
kê-wâpahk kik-êspicinânaw , itwêw . Tomorrow morning we shall move camp to that place,” he said.
â , miywêyihtamiyiwa otawâsimisah . Very glad were his children.
kêkâc wâpanih-mîcisôwak . They ate almost till dawn.
iyikohk ômah kâ-pêtâwiht , kêkâc kahkiyaw kitâwak . As much as this was, which had been brought for them, they devoured nearly all of it.
êh-wâpaniyik , wawêyîwak , ê-sipwêhtêcik , êh-itohtêcik ôhih mistanaskwah . The next morning they made ready and set out to go to Badger's.
piyis tipiskâyiw ê-pimohtêcik ; namoya nipâwak . Night fell while they were on the march; they did not stop to sleep.
piyis wâpaniyiw . Day broke.
êkwah êwakô kapê-kîsik pimohtêwak . All that day, too, they marched.
êh-otâkosik , êkoyikohk takohtêwak ôh îtahk êh-wîkiyit mistanaskwah . In the evening they arrived there where Badger was camping.

kwayâcih-pânaham awa sikâkoskwêw itah ta-kapêsiyit ostêsah , ohpim êkotah ê-sakâyik , êkota êh-ntawi-kapêsiyit . Skunk-Woman beforehand had cleared away the snow where she planned for her brother to camp, off to one side in a grove, off where he was to go and camp.

ôtêh , ât êh-itât awa sikâkoskwêw ostêsah , namoya tâpwêhtam awa wâkayôs , itah êh-kapêsit awa wâkayôs . Although Skunk-Woman said, “Over here!” to her brother, that Grizzly paid no heed, but camped right there.

êh-kîsih-cimatâcik wîkiwâw ,
âh , âstamitik , nâtahtân wiyâsah , itêw otawâsimisah . When they had set up their tent, “Now, come here, children, let us fetch meat,” he told his children. CHECK nâtahtân
kahkiyaw sipwêhtêwak . They all went forth.
êkwah awa sikâkoskwêw mistahi mâkwêyimôw , êh-kiskêyihtahk ê-wîh-otinamiyit onîmâwiniwâw . Then that Skunk-Woman felt very sad, when she knew that he was going to take their food-supplies.
ahâ , nîstâh , pîhtokê ! ât êh-itât awa mistanask , namoya tâpwêhtam awa wâkayôs . “Well, brother-in-law, come in!” said Badger, in vain, to him, but Grizzly paid no heed.
kahkiyaw wiyâsah otinam . He took all the meat.
â , ntawâsimisitik , kîwêhtatâk , itêw otawâsimisah . “Come, children, bring it home,” he bade his children.
ôho wiyâsah âwatâwak mistahi . They carried off the meat in great quantity.
kahkiyaw otinam , êh-mêsci-kîwêhtatât wiyâsah . He took all, carrying home the meat to the last bit.
êkwah pîhtokêw awa wâkayôs ; kahkiyaw otinam omîciwiniyiwa mistanaskwah , kahkiyaw êh-maskamât . Then Grizzly went inside the tent; he took all of Badger's food supplies, robbing him of all.
êkwah awa sikâkoskwêw mâtôw , êh-mawihkâtahk , onîmâwinah êh-mihtâtahk . And Skunk-Woman cried, grieving for it, lamenting her store of food.

omis îtêw :
niwîkimâkan , êkos êcik âni kê-nipahâhkatosoyahk , itwêw , pêskis êh-mâtot . She said, “Husband, and so we are to starve to death,” she said, weeping.
kiyâm âpê ! itwêw awa mistanask ; “Stay still where you are!” said Badger;
ayîsk kakêpâtisiw kistês , itêw owîkimâkanah . “Your brother is incorrigible, and that is the end of it,” he told his wife.
êkosi mitoni nama kêkway ayâw ta-mîcit awa mistanask . And so Badger had absolutely nothing to eat.
êkwah wâkayôs mistahi ayâw mîciwin ; pisisik mîcisôwak awa wâkayôs . And Grizzly and his household did nothing but eat.
piyis kinwês nama kêkway mîciw awa mistanask ; wîh-nipahâhkatosôw piyisk . At last Badger had eaten nothing for a long time; at last he was almost dead from hunger.
iyâtah-wâpamâcih mostoswah , namoya wîh-nipahêw . Although he would see buffalo, he did not care to kill them.

misawât kahkiyaw tit-ôtinêw awa wâkayôs , nipahimakih , êh-itêyihtahk , êk ôhci namoya wîh-nipahêw . “In any case that Grizzly will take them all, if I kill any,” he thought, and that was why he did not care to kill them.
piyis mînah nôhtêhkatêw awa wâkayôs , êh-kitât nîmâwinah . At last Grizzly also was hungry, when he had eaten up the supplies.
kîtahtawê kâ-wâpamât mostoswah . Then once he saw some buffaloes.
itohtêw awa wâkayôs . Grizzly went there.

seg.q: hâw , nistah , mistanask ! kisiwâk ôtah ayâwak mostoswak .
seg.gloss: “Listen, brother-in-law, Badger! Close by here are some buffaloes.

p.seg: minahôh ; kinôhtêhkatânânaw , itwêw . Make a killing, we are all hungry,” he said.
êkwah mistanask pasikôw , êh-ati-sipwêhtêt , êh-cikahkwâtât . Then Badger rose to his feet and went out to spear them.
kahkiyaw nipahêw . He killed them all.

têpwêw awa wâkayôs
nitawâsimisitîk , mêscihêw kisisiwâw ! âstamitik ! pê-nâtamok wiyâs , itwêw , êh-ati-sipwêhtêt . Grizzly hallooed, “Children, your uncle has got them all! Come here! Come fetch the meat,” he cried, and started out.

âsay awa mistanask pêyak êh-wiyinowit ôhi mostoswah êkonih wîh-otinêw ; êkoyikohk kâ-takohtêt awa wâkayôs . By this time Badger was on the point of taking one of those buffaloes, a fat one; just then up came Grizzly.

seg.gloss: “What is the idea, Badger?”
“Why, I wanted it, seeing that I have some buffaloes, I wanted to have some meat.

p.seg: mistahi nnôhtêhkatânân , nîstâ , itwêw mistanask . We are very hungry, brother-in-law,” said Badger.

omis îtwêw wâkayôs :
âyêhtân êtokê kiy-ôwiyâsimiyan êh-wiyinot ! itêw ! Grizzly cried: “And so you are going to have a fat one for your share of the meat, are you, indeed!” he said to him.
â , mâka kisîm nôhtêhkatêw , itwêw . “Oh, but your sister is hungry,” said he.
tâpwê pikoh otinêw awa wâkayôs ôhi mistanaskwah , ê-sakipitonênât , êh-kwâhciwêpinât . In truth, Grizzly merely took hold of Badger, seizing him by the arm, and flung him off to one side.
kîwê ! nama kêkway kik-âyân wiyâs , itêw mistanaskwah . “Go home! You shan't have any meat at all,” he told Badger.
kîwêw mistanask ; kostêw wâkayôsah . Badger went home; he was afraid of Grizzly.

kahkiyaw otinam wiyâsah awa wâkayôs , êkwah êh-otâkosik , itohtêw awa sikâkoskwêw itah ê-kîh-wiyanihtâkêwiht . Grizzly took all the meat. [sic] The, in the evening, that Skunk-Woman went to the place where the butchering had been done.
wâpahtam mihkoh . She saw some blood.

êwakoh otinam ; kîwêhtatâw , êh-asiwatât otaskihkohk , pahkih êwakô êh-kîsisahk mihko , êh-mîcicik awa mistanask . She took this; she took it home and put in it [sic] her kettle, and heated a part of it, of that blood, for herself and Badger to eat.
piyisk êh-tipiskâyik , piyisk kawisimôwak . Then, when night came, they went to bed.
êh-mêkwâ-pimisihkik , nam êskw êh-nipâcik , kâ-pêhtawâcik awâsisah êh-mâtôyit . As they lay there, before they had gone to sleep, they heard a child crying.
waniskâw awa sikâkoskwêw , êh-kotawêt , kâ-wâpamât awâsisah askihkohk êh-asiwasôyit , êh-mâtôyit . Skunk-Woman got up and lit a fire, and there she saw a child in the kettle, crying.

otinêw , êh-kitimâkinawât ,
kik-ayâwânaw , êh-itât owîkimâkanah . She took it up, looking upon it with tender pity, and saying to her husband, “Let us keep him.”

ômis îtwêw mistanask :
namoya ka-kîw-ohpikihânaw . Badger said, “We shall not be able to raise him.

seg.gloss: What is he to wear?
He will starve to death, seeing that we go hungry.

p.seg: kiyâm wayawîwâpin , itêw . Throw him out of doors, do,” he told her.
nka-kitimahâw , itwêw awa sikâkoskwêw . “I shall be destroying him,” said Skunk-Woman.
wayawîwêpin kiyâm , itwêw mistanask . “Do throw him out of the house,” said Badger.

êkwah awa sikâkoskwêw ocêmêw , êh-wayawîwêpinât ,
tâpwê nikitimahâw , êh-itwêt . Then Skunk-Woman kissed him as she threw him out, saying, “Truly, I am destroying him.”

kâ-pê-pîhtokêtâcimoyit ôh âwâsisah ,
notokêsiw , otin ; wayawîwêpin . Into the tent the child came crawling, and, “Old woman, pick him up; throw him out.”
otinêw away iskwêw , êh-wayawîwêpinât , êh-ma-mawimowit . The woman picked him up and flung him outside, as he cried.

êh-pê-pîhtokêyit , êh-pimohcêsiyit ,
hâ , notokêsiw , wayawîwêpin , itwêw . When he came in, toddling, “Ho, old woman, throw him out,” he said.
âsa mîna wayawîwêpinêw . Again she threw him out.

kâ-pê-pîhtokêyit nâpêsisah ,
êhâ , nôtokêsiw , wayawîwêpin . Into the lodge came a boy, “Haha, old woman, throw him outside.”
êh-âta-ma-mawimowit , wayawîwêpinêw . Although the child wept, she threw him out.

kâ-pê-pîhtokêyit oskinîkiwa mistah ê-miyosiyit , êh-wîtisiyit , êkosi ôtê wêskwâhtêmihk ê-nahapiyit , ê-mosêskatêyit , In came a youth, very handsome, with long hair, and sat down in the place of honour, opposite the door, naked as he was,

seg.gloss: and “Hah, old woman, lend him your blanket-robe; let him wrap himself in it.”

p.seg:
êkosi ômisi itwêw awaw oskinîkiw :
nôhtâ , itêw ôhi mistanaskwah ,
kitayân cî pahkêkinos , apihcacikos-pahkêkinos ? Then thus spoke that youth: “Father,” he said to that Badger, “have you a little scrap of leather, of kid-leather?”

seg.gloss: “Yes, I shall look for it.”

p.seg: êkwah nitonam ; miskam . He looked for it and found it.
hâw , ôm îtah , nikosis , itwêw mistanask . “Now, here you are, my son,” said Badger.
ômisi tôtam : pahpawipayihtâw aw oskinîkiw pahkêkin . This is what he did: the youth shook the piece of leather.
miskotâkay ta-wîh-ihtakon ! itwêw awaw oskinîkiw . “Let there be a coat!” said the youth.
tâpwê , miskotâkay . And really, there was a coat, which he put on.
postasâkêw . [no translation] [which he put on.]

kêyâpic ,
pêtâh pahkêkinos , itwêw awa oskinîkiw . Again, “Bring a scrap of leather,” said the youth.
mîna miyêw . He gave him another.
awa oskinîkiw pahpawipayihtâw . The youth took it.
t-ôtâsiyân ta-wiy-ihtakonwah ! itwêw . “Let there be breeches for me!”
tâpwê , mitâsah . Truly, there were some breeches.

êkwah ômis îtwêw aw ôskinîkiw , watôw-awâsis :
nôhtâh , mostoswayânis , pâhpâkôwêwayânis ! then this youth, Clot-Child, spoke thus: “Father, a bit of buffalo hide, a bit with the wool on it!” FIX spacing error in TEI file (omisitwew)
otinêw . He took it; [sic]
pahpawipayihêw awa oskinîkiw . he shook it in the air, that youth.

itêw ,
ta-wîh-misêkisiw , tit-ôtakohpiyân , êskanak ta-kikamocik , mînah waskasiyah ta-kikamoyit ! itwêw awa oskinîkiw . He said, “Let it be a whole fur, for my blanket-robe, and let the horns be on it, and the hoofs!” said the youth.
tâpwêh kikamoyiwa êskanah mîna waskasiyah , mostoswaskasiyah . Truly the horns were on it and the hoofs, the buffalo-hoofs.
êkos êkonih akwanahôw aw oskinîkiw . So then the youth wrapped himself in it.

seg.gloss: “Now, father, if you have a bit of otterskin, give it to me.”

p.seg: tâpwê nitonawêw awa mistanask ; miskawêw . So Badger looked for it; he found some.
hâw , îtah , nikosis , itêw . “Here, son,” he said to him.
otinam awâ oskinîkiw ; pahpawipayihêw . The youth took it; he swung it up and down.

ta-misiwêsiw awah nikikwayân , t-ôtastotniyân ! itwêw aw oskinîkiw . He said, “Let this otterskin be whole, that I may have it for a hat!” said the youth.

seg.gloss: “And now, father, go cut some saskatoon willows, for a bow.”

p.seg: tâpwêh ntawi-kîskikaham awa mistanask . So Badger went out and cut some.
mistahi miywêyihtam oskinîkiwah êh-ayâwât . He was very glad that he had the young man.

êkwah ,
tân-tah awah êh-ohtohtêt ? itêyihtam awa mistanask , ôh ôkosisah . And, “whence did he come?” thought Badger of his son.
namoya kiskêyihtam . He did not know.

askihkohk kâ-kîh-asiwatâcik mihkoh , êyok ôhci ayîsiyinîwiw aw oskinîkiw , osâm êh-kisiwâsit , ôhih êh-kitimahimiht mistanaskwah . From the blood that they had put in the kettle that youth had taken shape as a human being, because he was too angry at the way Badger was being abused.
êkosi aw oskinîkiw ômis îsiyîhkâsôw : watôw-awâsis . Therefore, this youth was named Clot-Child.

watôw
ntisiyîhkâtânân . Just as blood that has been standing long grows hard; this we call “a clot.”
êkotah ohcih aw oskinîkiw êh-ohcît , êkosi watôw-awâsis . And from this it was that the youth sprang; therefore, he was Clot-Child.
êkwah ôh acosisah osîhtâwak . Then they made those arrows.
piyisk wâpaniyiw , kahkiyaw êh-kîsihtâcik . At last morning came, and they had finished them all.
êkwah nama kêkway mîcisôwak . Now they had nothing to eat.
êh-apicik kîksêpâ , kâ-pêtohtêt awah wâkayôs . As they sat there, early in the morning, up came that Grizzly.

hâ , nîstâh mistanask , minahoh ôki mostoswak , itwêw . He said, “Ha, brother-in-law Badger, make a killing of those buffalo.”

êkwah tânihih êh-wiyinoyit , êwakonih têhtapiw awa mistanask . Then Badger sat down on whichever one was the fattest.
nîstâh , aw êkwah niya niwîh-ayâwâw , itêw wâkayôsah . “Brother-in-law, this one, now I want to have,” he said to Grizzly.

ayîtê êtokê kiyah kiy-âyâwat êh-wiyinot ? itwêw wâkayôs ;
â , namoya nistâh ! “And do you really suppose you can have the fat one?” cried Grizzly; “Oh, dear, no, brother-in-law!”

seg.gloss: “Brother-in-law, even now your sister and I are hungry!”

mâkah aw oskinîkiw paspâpiw , êh-kitâpamât ôhtêwiyah . But that youth was peeking out of the tent, watching his father.

cikahkwêwêpahwêw ; otinêw ospitoniyihk , wîkiwâyihk êsiwêpinât . he knocked him headlong; he grabbed him by the arm and flung him toward his tent.
aw oskinîkiw wacôw-awâsis kisiwâsiw , ôhtâwiyah êh-cikahkwêwêpahomiht ; The youth Clotkin flew into a rage, when his father was knocked down;
ati-wayawîw , êh-ati-sipwêhtêt , ôhtâwiyah ê-itohtêt . he came out and started toward his father.
cîk êy-ihtât , êkoyikohk waniskâyiwah ôhtâwiyah ; kipistanêhomâwah . When he got near, his father got up; he was bleeding at the nose from the blow.

êh-wâpamât awa wâkayôs ôh ôskinîkiwah êh-pêtohtêyit ,
yâh yahâh , nitihkwâ , êkosi mâna ntôtawâw êh-pa-pâhpisihak kôhtâwiy , êtamihicih , mihcêt nêpahâci mostoswah ! When Grizzly saw the youth approaching, “Yoho, nephew, this is the way I treat your father, just by way of teasing him, whenever he makes me glad by killing buffalo!” FIX TEI file: nâma for mâna

namoya êh-pa-pâhpisihiyan , nîstâh , mistahi êh-kwatakihiyan , nîstâh ! Thus spoke Badger, as he kept throwing blood from his nose: “Not by way of teasing me, brother-in-law, but because you sorely torment me, brother-in-law!”

cêmâk aw ôskinîkiw pîkiskwêw ,
tâpwê mistahi kikitimahâw nôhtâwiy ! itêw , ohcâhcâpiyah ohci êh-pakamahwât ôhi wâkayôsah . At once the youth spoke up, “In truth, you are cruelly abusing my father!” he said to Grizzly, and struck him with his bow.

mitoni tâskiwêpahwêw , ospiskwanihk ôtê êh-âkôpayihoyit ôhtâwiyah mistanaskwah , êh-kwêskipayihot . He struck a big gash in the other's body; his father, Badger, stayed behind his back, and he faced about.
âsa minah ômis îsi mâmawôpayiyiwah wâkayôsah ; pê-môskîstâk . Again Grizzly, like this, pulled himself together, and came attacking the youth.
âsa mîna pakamahwêw ; tâskiwêpahwêw mîna . Again he struck him; again he cleft him with the blow.
â , nohtâ , pêyak êyôkô otihtin ! itêw ôhtâwiyah aw oskinîkiw . “Come, father, take hold of him on one side!” the youth bade his father.
mina wîsta napatê otihtinêw ; êh-mâh-maniswât , nipahêw . He himself took hold of him on the other side; he kept slashing him until he killed him.
êkwah awah wâkayôs otawâsimisah , ostêsimâw awa pê-môskîstawêw ôh ôskinîkiwah . Then the oldest of Grizzly's sons came attacking the youth.

tâpwê kikitimahin , wacôw-awâsis , nôhtâwiy kâ-nipahat , itwêw . He cried, “Truly, you ruin me, Clotkin, in killing my father.”
êh-pâpayiyit , aw oskinîkiw pimwêw ; nipahêw . As he drew near, the youth shot him; he slew him.
kotakah minah pê-môskîstâk ; êkonih mînah nipahêw , êh-pimwât . Another also came attacking him; this one, too, he killed with a bowshot.
piyis kahkiyaw môskîstâk ; kahkiyaw mêscihêw ôhi wâkayôsah . Finally all of them attacked him; he did away with all of those bears.
miywêyihtam awa mistanask êh-mêcihimiht , êh-kîh-kitimahikot . Badger rejoiced that they were exterminated, who had tormented him.

mistah ê-kîh-ayât , ômis îtwêw :
â , nôhtah , kika-nakatitin . When he had much of it, he spoke as follows: “Now, father, I shall leave you.
ôtêh nik-êtohtân kâ-wîkihk , itwêw awa wacôw-awâsis . I shall go where people dwell,” said Clotkin.

seg.gloss: “Oh, dear!”

âhag , itwêw mistanask . “Very well,” said Badger.
tâpwê pasikôw , êh-ocêmât ôhtâwiyah êkwah okâwiyah . Thereupon he arose and kissed his father and mother.
êkos îsi wayawîw , ê-sipwêhtêt . Then he went out and departed.
mayaw êh-âkawêwêt , otinam acosis , êh-pimotâhkwêt . As soon as he was round a bend, he took an arrow and shot it.

seg.gloss: “Now, on this arrow of mine let me stand!

tâpwê êkotê pahkisin . Really, there he came to earth.

êkosi itohtêw mîkiwâhpihk ; pêyak nôtokêsiwah mistahi êh-ktimâkisiyit , êh-pêyakoyit , êkotah pîhtokêw . So he went to a lodge; where a poor old woman dwelt alone, there he entered.
ay-apih , nôsisimis ! itik . “Be seated, my grandchild!” she said to him.
êyak ôma otênaw mistah ê-âyimisit wâkayôs êkotah êh-okimâwit . In that village a most terrible bear was the chief.
nê ôtawâsimisah , nîsw îskwêwah , nîso nâpêwah . He had four children, two women, and two men.

kîspin êh-kiskêyihtahk mostoswah nêpahimihcih , kahkiyaw êh-otinahk wiyinwah awa wâkayôs kâ-okimâwit , êkwah mêkwâc nôhtêhkatêwak , êkot êh-ay-ayât awa wacôw-awâsis . Whenever he learned that a buffalo had been killed, that bear who was chief would take all the fat meat, so that now they were starving, there where Clotkin was staying.
namoya kiskêyihtam awa wacôw-awâsis . Clotkin did not know that.
êh-wîhkwêstêyikih mîkiwâhpah , tawâyihk êh-astêyik pîhtokahân . Where the tents stood in a circle, there in the centre was a buffalo-close.

seg.gloss: And the chief, if anyone drives buffalo into the corral, the chief will give him his daughters, and very handsome young women they are.”

êkosi ômis îtêw :

Then she also told him: “But even when buffaloes are killed, that bear takes all the fat meat, whatever meat is at all good, and nobody can kill him, so terrible is he.” merged original 17.99.3 and 17.99.4 - not a sentence break
hâh hâw , nôhkôh , nika-nâcipahân ici , itêw ôhkomah . “Well the, grandmother, I shall make a round-up, never fear,” he told his grandmother.
piyisk kawisimôwak . In due time they went to bed.
kîksêpâ êh-waniskât awah wacôw-awâsis , kêyâpic nipâyiwah ôhkomah . In the morning, when Clotkin got up, his grandmother still slept.
êkos îsi wayawîw , ê-sipwêhtêt , mostoswah ê-nâtât . Thus he went out of the lodge and away, to fetch buffalo.
wâhyaw êh-ayât , mostoso-mêyah mâwacihtâw , ê-nâh-nâwayôstât , omis îsi , mostoso-mêyah . When he was far off, he gathered [no translation] and laid them in a row, like this.

omis îtwêw :
pasikôk ! pasikôk ! pasikôk ! itwêw . He spoke: “Arise ye! Arise ye! Arise ye!”

p.seg:
kiyah , itêw ,
namoya ka-pîhtokân . But you,” he said to the one, “you will not go in.

seg.gloss: You will go over this way, a little ways up the river.
The dogs will set upon you; and the children will shoot at you.

â , niyâk êkwa ! pimipayik ! And then, “So now, off with you! Run!”

êh-pôn-âpihta-kîsikâyik , takosinwak ôki mostoswak , êkwah awô mostos pêyak êh-kawâhkacosot , êwakô kont îtêh ispayîw . After mid-day those buffalo arrived. [sic] The one buffalo that was lean ran off by itself somewhere.
êkos ôki ayîsiyiniwak êh-wâpamâcik êh-kawâhkacosoyit , namoya pisiskêyimêwak . When the people saw that it was entirely lean, they paid no attention to it.
atimwak mâmawôhkawêwak , piyisk nâpêsisak ê-pâh-pimwâcik , awa nôtokêsiw wîkihk êy-ispayiyit . The dogs set upon it, and at last the boys kept shooting at it, as it ran toward that old woman's lodge.
êkotah nipahik awâsisah awa mostos . There the boys killed that buffalo.

awa nôtokêsiw mistahi miywêyihtam ,
êkwah wiyâs nikah-ayân , êh-itêyihtahk . The old woman was very glad, thinking, “Now I shall have meat.”
êkwah awa wacôw-awâsis âkawâyihk ayêw ; Now Clotkin was behind some obstacle;

namoya wâpamik ayîsiyiniwah ,
tâpiskôc awâsis êh-kitimâkisit , êh-mâyâtisit , êkosi nik-êsinâkosin ! êh-itwêt awah wacôw-awâsis . the people did not see him, and, “Like a poor, ugly child let me look!” said Clotkin.
êkosi kîwêw ; ôhkomah , êh-takohtêt , mêkwâc wînihtakêyiwah . Then he went home; as he walked up, his grandmother was busy skinning and cutting up the carcass.
hây hây hây , nôhkô ! êkwah wiyâs kik-ayânânaw ! itwêw . “Splendid, grandmother! Now we shall have meat!” he cried.
êhag , itik ôhkomah . “Yes,” his grandmother answered him.
êkwah nêkih kotakak mostoswak , êkonih kahkiyaw nipahêwak ôk ayîsiyiniwak . But those other buffalo, the people killed them all.
mâka mînah awa wâkayôs k-âyimisit kahkiyaw ôtinam wiyinwah , êh-kitimahât ôwîcêwâkanah . And, as usual, that terrible bear took all the fat meat and left his followers in want.
êkwah awah wacôw-awâsis êh-pîhtokatâyit ôhkomah wiyâsah , kahkiyaw pîhtokatâyiwa . Clotkin's grandmother brought the meat into the lodge, all of it.

seg.gloss: “Grandmother, cover up your meat!”

p.seg:
êkwah awa nôtokêsiw ê-kîh-akwanahahk ,
nôhkô , ntawi-kîskatahah nêwô nîpisîsah . And when the old woman had covered it, “Grandmother, go chop four willow-withes.”
tâpwê awa nôtokêsiw ntawi-kîskataham ; pêtâw . So the old woman went out and chopped them off; she brought them.
ôh , îtê , nôsisê , itwêw . “Here they are, grandson,” she said.

seg.gloss: “Grandmother, go out of doors! Stand there, outside the lodge!”

p.seg:
tâpwê êkwah awa wacôw-awâsis pâh-pasastêham wiyâsah ,
paskonê , paskonê ! êh-itwêt . Then that Clotkin whipped the meat, saying “Be fat, be fat!”
tâpwê wiyinôwiyiwa . Truly, the pieces turned into fat meat.

seg.gloss: “Grandmother, come in; now do your cooking; let us eat!”

p.seg: awa nôtokêsiw êh-pâskinahk owiyâsima , êh-wâpahtahk êh-wiyinowiyikih , kâwiy akwanaham . When that old woman uncovered her meat and saw that it was fat, she covered it again.

seg.gloss: “Grandchild, grandchild! We shall not keep these.

p.seg: kiskêyihtahkih aw ôkimâw , ta-pê-nâtam , itwêw . If the chief learns of this, he will come and get it,” she said.
â , nôhkô , mîcisotân , itwêw . “Oh, grandmother, let us eat,” he said.
tâpwêh êkwah paminawasôw awa nôtokêw . so then the old woman set about cooking.
awa wacôw-awâsis misiwêw ôtônihk oma wiyin sinikohtitâw , êh-tômisit . Clotkin smeared the fat meat all round his mouth, greasing his face.
êkosi êkwah wayawîw . Then he went out of the lodge.

seg.gloss: “Grandmother, make dried meat; hang up your fats.
I am going to play a bit.”
“Grandchild, wipe your mouth!”
“So I have, grandmother!”

p.seg: êkos îsi sipwêhtêw , ôhi k-âyimisiyit wâkayôsah êkoni ôkosisiyiwah êh-ntawih-wîci-mêtawêmât . Thus he went off to play with the sons of the terrible bear.

kâ-wâpamikot mistah êh-tômisit otônihk watâhk mînah , êkosi kîwêyiwah ôhi nâpêsisah , êh-ntawi-wîhtamawâyit ôhtâwiyiwa . When those boys saw him with grease all over his face and his bellly too, they went home to tell their father.

ômis îtwêyiwa :
nôhtâh , mistah êh-tômisit ôtah aw awâsis kâ-kitimâkisiyit ôhkomah ! They said, “Father, that child whose grandmother is so poor is all greased, here!”

wâh , namoya ! itwêw wâkayôs ;
nkîh-wâpamâw êh-kawâhkatosoyit , itwêw . “Dear me, no!” cried the bear; “I saw him, and his beast was entirely lean.”
êkosi kîwêpahtâw aw wacôw-awâsis ôhkomah wîkisiyihk . Now Clotkin ran back to his grandmother's tiny lodge.
êh-apit pîhcâyihk , kâ-pê-paspiskwêyiyit ôhi nâpêsisah . When he sat down inside, there came those boys sticking their heads into the door.
wâpahtamiyiwah wiyinwah . They saw the fat meat.
kîwêyiwah . They went back.

ômis îtwêyiwah ôhkomah :
nôsisê , âta kikîh-kitahamâtn ê-wîh-itohtêyan . his grandmother said, “Grandchild, didn't I tell you not to go there?
kahkiyaw ôhi ta-pêw-otinam anâ wâkayôs , itwêyiwa . That bear will come and take it all,” she said.
nâhâ nâpêsis âcimostawêw ôhtâwiyah . That boy told his father.
mistahi wiyinwah ayâwak mîna kâhkêwakwa êh-wiyinôwiyikih , êkos îtêw . “They have much fat meat and much dried meat of the fattest,” he told him.
pasikôw aw ôkimâw , êh-itohtêt ; êh-yôhtênahk , êh-itâpit , kâh-wâpahtahk . The chief rose to his feet and went there; when he opened the door and looked in, there he saw it.

seg.gloss: “Come, Pot-Belly Child, I have come to get your grandmother's dried meat and the fats.”

p.seg: ahag , otinah , itêw . “Very well, take them,” he answered him.
otinamiyiwa kahkiyaw , êh-maskamikocik , êh-kîwêhtatâyit . He took it all, robbing them, and carried it home.
mâtoyiwa ôhkoma ê-mawihkâtamiyit owiyinomiyiwa . The boy's grandmother wept over the loss of her fat meats.

ômis îtêw :
kiyâm apê , nôhkô ; nika-nâtên kiwiyinoma , itêw . He said to her, “Sit still, grandmother; I will fetch your fat meats.”

seg.gloss: “Do not, grandchild; he will kill you.”
“No, grandmother; I will fetch them!”

p.seg: êkos âti-pasikôw , êh-itohtêt . So he got up and went there.

êh-yôhtênahk , omis îtwêw :
mâski-maskwah , npê-nâtên nôhkom owiyinoma . When he opened the door he cried, “Cripple-Bear, I have come to get my grandmother's fat meats.”

seg.gloss: “Yes, yes, take them.”
seg.note: FIX original file's duplication of first sentence from next paragraph.

p.seg: pîhtokêw ; pasikôyiwa ê-sakipitonênikot , êh-wayawîwêpinikot . He entered; the other rose to his feet, seized him by the arm, and flung him out of the lodge. FIX typo in orig (pihkotew --> pihtokew)
âsa mina pasikôw . He got up again.

pîhtokêw ,
nipê-nâtên nôhkom owiyinoma , êh-itât . He entered, saying to the other, “I have come to fetch my grandmother's fat meats.”

seg.gloss: “Yes!”

p.seg:
âsay awah awa mâski-maskwah okosisah ômisi itwêyiwah :
nôhtâh , êkâyâ pisiskêyîm ! Already that Cripple-Bear's sons spoke thus: “Father, do not heed him!

seg.gloss: Never does anyone deal thus with you.

seg.q: êh-manitôwit êtokw âwa ! nitakis êtokw âwa kê-mantôwit !
seg.gloss: I suppose this creature has some unusual power! Not by a long ways will he have mystic power!
He is nearly bursting at the belly, so pot-bellied is he.”

p.seg: ê-wîh-otinahk owiyinoma , ôhkomah , âsay mînah kâ-pasikôyit ôh ôkimâwa . As he was about to take his fat meats, that is, his grandmother's, there again that chief rose to his feet.
nawatinamwêw ospitoniyiwa , êh-nâh-nâtwânamwât ôhô wâkayôsah ; mîna otôniyiw tâwâpiskanêpitêw . He took hold of the bear's arms and broke first one, then the other; and he tore his mouth way open.
êkosi nama kêkway kîh-miciminamiyiwa . So now the other could not hold anything.

êkosi êkwah kahkiyaw ôwiyinomiyiwa ôhkomah , okâhkêwakomiyiwa kîwêhtatâw , aspin êh-ma-mawimoyit ôhih wâkayôsah ,
wâh , wâh ! êh-itwêyit . Thereupon he took home all his grandmother's fat meats and slices of dried meat, while back there the bear was howling, “Oh dear, oh dear!”
pêtâw wîkiwâhk . He brought them to their lodge.
êkos ây-apiw êkwah . Then he stayed there.

êkwah awa wâkayôs okosisah ômisiy itik :
êkosi kâ-kîh-ititân , nôhtâh ; namoya kitâpwêhtawin , itik ; Then the bear's sons said to him, “This is what I told you, father; you did not listen to me,” they told him;
hâw , kakwêh-iyinihkâhisoh kispitonah mina kitôn , itik . Now then, try to cure your arms and your mouth,” they said to him.

seg.gloss: “Yes.”

- ôk ôskinîkiskwêwak -
ê-isi-nîsiyit miyih . “Now then,” his sons said to him, “Now, father, my sisters here” those young women “my two sisters here do you give to him.

seg.gloss: He will restore you to life, if he can marry them.
“Very well.”

hâ , nya , kîwê , itêw ôhi nôtokêsiwah . “Very well,” said Clotkin, “be off, go home,” he told the old woman.

kâwih miywâsiniyiwa . They were well again.
mînah otôniyiw êwako mînah ê-sinikonamwât , êkosi miyw-ayâyiwa . Also his mouth he rubbed for him, and he got well.
êkosi kîwêw ôhkomah wîkiyihk ; êkotê ayâw . Then he went back to his grandmother's lodge; there he stayed.
piyis tipiskâyiw . At last night fell.

namoya kisiwâk wîtapimik , êh-pakwâtikot . She did not sit close to him, for she hated him.

nisîm , tâpwê namoya kipakwâtâw awiyak êh-wîninâkosit ! êh-itwêyit . Then the younger one, by whose side he sat, prepared some berries and gave them him to eat, as he began to eat them, the elder sister said: “Sister, truly you do not mind if a person looks dirty!”

êkosi êôkô êh-tipiskâk , êkwah êh-nipâcik , ômis îtêw ôh ôwîkimâkanah :
hâw , kitâpacihon êkâ kâ-pakwâsiyan , itêw ; Thereupon, the next night when they went to bed, he said to his wife: “There, you did well by yourself in not rejecting me,” he told her;

seg.q: namoya êkosi ta-isinâkosiyân ôma kâ-wâpamiyan êsinâkosiyân .
seg.gloss: “Not thus shall I look, as now you see me.
Tomorrow I shall bring in some buffalo.

seg.q: wîhtamawâhkan kôhtâwiy êkâ wiyah kâ-kitimahât ayîsiyiniwah ; kây êkwah êkosi tit-ôtinam wiyinwah ; êkosi itâhkan .
seg.gloss: Do you then tell your father not to deprive the people; he is not to take the fat meats; tell him this.
Now, when I bring the buffalo, I shall come walking at the head.
I shall be wearing a leather coat; I shall have breeches of the like;

seg.q: êkwah mostoswayân nik-âkwanahon ; êskanak ta-kikamôwak mînah waskasiyak .
seg.gloss: and a buffalo-robe I shall have for my blanket; there will be horns on it and hoofs.
And an otterskin I shall have as my headgear.
That will be I.
I shall enter the buffalo-pound.
The buffalo will follow at my heels.
Opposite the entrance I shall climb up on the hurdle; up there I shall stay.
You will come there; you will bring stewed berries.
There we shall eat; we two shall eat together.

êkosi nipâwak . Then they went to sleep.

namwâc nipâyiwa onâpêma , âsay ê-sipwêhtêyit , êh-nâtâyit mostoswah . Her husband was not sleeping there; he had already gone away to fetch the buffalo.
kiyipa wâpaniyiw . Soon day broke.
êkosi ê-kîh-waniskâcik , omisah ê-kîh-mîcisocik , wayawîw , ôhtâwiyah êh-itohtêt . And so, when they had got up and she and her elder sister had eaten, she went out of the lodge, to her father.

ômisiy itêw :

seg.gloss: “Oh, dear me, daughter, why did you not stop him?

p.seg: ta-kawaciw nnahâhkisîm , itwêw . My son-in-law will freeze,” said he.

seg.q:

seg.gloss: “But this is what your son-in-law says to you, father: ‘When I bring the buffalo, he is not to do that way, to take the fat meats, to rob his followers of the fat meats,’ your son-in-law tells you, and that you are to announce that they shall watch for buffalo.
That is what your son-in-law said.”

seg.q: âhag , ntânis , nika-pônihtân ; k-êtwêt nnahâhkisîm nka-tôtên .
seg.gloss: “Very well, daughter, I shall stop; as my son-in-law says I shall do.”

êkosi wayawîw awa kisêyiniw , ômis êh-itwêt :
oskinîkîtik , asawâpik . Then that old man went outside and said, “Young men, be on the lookout.
kayâs kîksêp êsah kî-sipwêhtêw ninahâhkisîm , êh-nâtât mostoswah , êh-itwêt awa kisêyiniw . Early in the morning, I hear, my son-in-law went out to fetch buffalo,” said the old man.
êkosi tâpwêw kapê-kîsik ay-asawâpiwak ôk ôskinîkiwak . Accordingly the young men kept watch all day.
êh-pôn-âpihtâ-kîsikâyik , kâ-pâpayiyit mostoswah . After the day had reached noon, there came the buffalo.

sâsay aw oskinîkiskwêw mînisah kîsisam ,
mâskôc takohtêcih , êy-itêyimât onâpêma . Already that young woman was cooking berries, thinking that doubtless her husband would soon arrive.

pôtih kisiwâk êh-pêy-ihtâyit , oskinîkiwak ôki kâ-wâpamâcik mistah êh-miyosiyit oskinîkiwah , nîkan êh-pê-pimipahâyit mostoswah , êh-askôkoyit . Behold, as the herd approached, those young men saw a very handsome youth leading at a run the buffalo, who followed at his heels.
namwâc nisitawêyimêwak ôh ôskinîkiwah . Not at all did they recognize that youth. FIX (nisita weyimewak --> nisitaweyimewak)

sêmâk pîhtokêw oma pîhtokahân ; êkotah ôhci wêskwâhtêmih kîhcêkosîpayihôw ôw oskinîkiw ; êkoyikohk êkwah pîhtokêpayiyiwa ôhi mostoswah . He promptly entered the pound; then at a point opposite the entrance that youth flung himself climbing to the top of the hurdle; at that moment the buffalo ran in.
sêmâk kâ-wâpamât êh-miyosiyit oskinîkiwah : êwakonih onâpêmah . At once she saw the handsome youth; he was her husband.
sêmâk wâsakâm ohci kîhcêkosîwak oskinîkiwak iskwêwak mînah , ê-wîh-wâpamâcik ôhi mostoswah . At once the young men and the women climbed up from all sides to see the buffalo.

êkosi êkwah êh-pâh-pâskiswâcik ôhi mostoswah , aw ôskinîkiskwêw mînisah wiyâkanihk ê-kîh-astât , kâ-ntaw-asamât owîkimâkanah . And while they were shooting at the buffalo, that young woman went to give her husband the berries which she had placed in a bowl.

êkwah miywêyimêw êh-miyosiyit , êh-wâpamât âsay osîma kâ-ta-kîhcêkosiyit , ê-wîh-miyâyit ôhi mênisah ,
nah ôhi otinah , êh-itâyit . now that he was handsome, she liked him, as she saw her younger sister climbing up to give him the berries, saying to him, “Here, take these.”
ôtinam aw ôskinîkiw . The youth took them.
kahkiyaw awiyah miywêyimik aw ôskinîkiw . Everyone liked the youth.
êkosi êkwah kîwêpahtâw awa ômisimâw kâ-kîh-pakwâtât . So then the elder sister, who had scorned him, ran home.

ômisi itêw okâwiyah :
nêkâh , pêtâh mînisah ! She said to her mother, “Mother, let me have some berries!”
miyik . Her mother gave her some.
êkwah kîsisam . Then she stewed them.

namoya mistahi kîsisam ,

êh-wâpamât osîmah êh-wîci-mîcisômâyit ,
nîst êkotê nika-mîcison , êh-itêyihtahk , tâpwê sipwêhtatâw omênisimah , êh-takohtatât . Because she had seen her younger sister eating with him, and thought, “I want to eat there, too,” she went off to take her berries there.
nah ôh ôtinah , itêw . “Here, take these,” she said to him.

aw oskinîkiw ômisiy itêw :
pê-âmaciwêhtatâh , itêw ôhi kâ-kîh-pakwâtikot . The youth told her, “Bring them up here,” he said to her who had scorned him. FIX (ômisiyitêw --> ômisiy itêw)
tâpwêh âmaciwêw aw îskwêw . So the young woman went up.

mwêhcih cîki êh-ayât , kâ-sôskoskawât mistikwah ; nîhcipayiw ; sîkipayiyiw omênisâpôm ; osit napatê micimôtâw ; kosâwêkocin . Just as she came near, she slipped on one of the logs; down she went; her berry-stew spilled; one of her feet was caught; she hung there in the air.
kahkiyaw awiyak mistahi pâhpiwak , iskwêwak , awâsisak . Everybody laughed, women, children, and all.
piyisk mâtôw aw oskinîkiskwêw , êh-nêpêwisit , ê-nîhcipayit . Soon the young woman wept with shame at having fallen down.
êkosiy isî êh-pihkohot . At last she got herself free.
kîwêw , êh-mâtot . She went home weeping.

ê-pîhtokêcik wîkiwâhk , awa kâ-kîh-pakwâtât ,

namôwya ! itwêw aw oskinîkiw . but, “No!” answered the youth.
wîst êkwah pakwâtêw , ê-kîh-pakwâtikot ôh ômisimâwa . Now it was his turn to scorn the elder sister, who had scorned him.
êkosi ay-ayâwak êkotah . So thus they dwelt there.
pisisik mâtôw awa ômisimâw , êh-nêpêwisit , ê-kîh-nîhcipayit . The elder sister unceasingly wept for shame at having fallen.
papâmohtêw tahkih . She was always wandering about.

piyisk ,

êh-nêpêwihit wacôw-awâsis , êh-pakwâsit , êkosi êh-itwêt . “Because Clotkin put me to shame and scorns me,” she would say.
a nôsisê , kahkiyaw awiyah kitimâkêyimik wacôw-awâsis , êh-itiht aw îskwêw , tahkih êh-papâh-mâtot . “Child, everyone is fond of Clotkin,” that woman would be told, as she went about and wept.

kîtahtawê pêyak nôtokêsiwah kâ-wâpamât ,

êh-nêpêwihit wacôw-awâsis , êh-itât . “Because Clotkin put me to shame,” she told her.
âh , cêskwah , nistah ta-nêpêwisit nka-tôtawâw , itêw awa nôtokêsiw . “There, wait a bit and I shall put him to shame,” the old woman told her.
kîtahtawê êh-papâmohtêt awa wacôw-awâsis , apisîs sîpîsis kâ-wâpahtahk . Presently as Clotkin went about, he came upon a little brook.
êkotêh itohtêw akâmihk aw ôskinîkiw kâ-miyosit . The handsome youth crossed it and went somewhere on the other side.

êh-ati-kîwêt , kâ-wâpamât nôtokêsiwa ,
nôsisêh , nayômin ; nama nikîh-âsôwahên , êh-itwêyit . On his way back, he saw an old woman, who said, “Grandson, take me on your back; I cannot get across.”

seg.gloss: “Grandmother, I shall make a little bridge so you can walk.”

piyisk ,
âhag , itêw . At last he consented.
nayômêw , êh-âsowahôhât . He took her on his back and carried her across.

ê-wîh-kakwê-pahkwatinât ôhi nôtokêsiwah , nama kîh-pihkohêw ; tâpiskôc pîwâpisk ospitoniyiwa oskâtiyiwah mîna . When he tried to pull the old woman off, he could not get her free; like iron were her arms and legs.

êkwah namoya wîh-kîwêw , ê-nêpêwisit , nôtokêsiwah êh-nayômât . So then he did not care to go home, [sic] for he ws ashamed to be carrying the old woman on his back. merged 17.186.2-3 FIX orig (wih-kiwew. -> wih-kiwew,) (eh-mayomat -> eh-nayomat)

piyisk kîwêw . So at last he went home.

êh-wâpamât aw ômisimâw , mistahi pâhpiw ,
tânêhki okistêyimoh wacôw-awâsis , nôtokêsiwah kâ-pêh-nayômât ? êh-itwêt . When that elder sister saw him, she laughed much, saying, “What was he so proud about, this Clotkin who comes with an old woman riding on his back?”
aw ôskinîkiskwêw êh-wâpamât onâpêmah , mistahê pakwâtâw . When the young woman saw her husband, she was greatly distressed.

seg.gloss: “‘Pig-vermilion,’ they will say!”

seg.gloss: “This is where you will stay fast;
‘Glowing fungus,’ the people will call you.
You will not be good for anything; you are too conceited. -
Now, come hither, all you people!

seg.gloss: Now then, my father-in-law, you, your children, and your wife, now, depart! Be off!

êkwah kiyawâw , - kotakah , -
kiyawâw mahîhkanak , êkwah kotakak kiyawâw mahkêsîsak , êkwah kotakak kiyawâw pisiwak , kiyawâw kîhkwahâkêsak ! And you” to the others “you they will call wolves, and you others foxes, and you others lynxes, and you coyotes!”

miywêyihtam awa mistanask êh-otihtikot okosisah . Badger was glad that his son had come to him.

êkosi pêyak tipiskâw êkotah êh-ayât , ômisiy itêw :

seg.gloss: So now, mortal men in the time to come will say of you, ‘Badger,’ these mortal men.
They will eat you, because you have been a good creature.

seg.gloss: a very good creature you will be; never will you bite people.

seg.q:
hâ , niya !
wîncoyêsîs
kik-êtikwak ayîsiyiniwak ; kika-môwikwak .
seg.gloss: There, go! ‘Polecat,’ mortal men will call you; they will eat you.”

p.seg: sipwêhtêw . She departed.

seg.q: êkwah niyah watôw ; mihkoh oma , watôw niyah .
seg.gloss: “As for me, a blood clot, blood am I.
And, therefore, nothing at all.”

p.seg: êkosi êkwah nama kêkway âcimowin . And so there is nothing at all of my tale.
êkoyikohk êh-iskwâk âtayôhkêwin . This is where the sacred story ends.
